abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Emergency Irrigation
            Rehabilitation Project for Afghanistan were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory; risk to development outcome was
            substantial; bank performance was moderately satisfactory
            and borrower performance was moderately satisfactory. Two
            main lessons learned included in this project: (i) general
            application lesson: this includes technical assistance team,
            emergency operations, development oriented phase, capacity
            building, and developing knowledge base; and (ii) project
            specific lessons is irrigation project criteria, monitoring
            and evaluation, use of advanced technologies, twinning
            arrangement and hydrological services.

17953211.majtheme: Rural development,Environment and natural resource management

repnme.cdata!:
Improving the lives of farmers through
            irrigation rehabilitation in Afghanistan

abstracts.cdata!:
As of December 31, 2011, the incremental
            irrigated area resulting from rehabilitation of more than
            750 irrigation schemes exceeded 800,000 hectares, which is
            more than the end-of-project target of 715,000 hectares. As
            of December 31, 2011, the number of beneficiaries is over
            840,000 people. Achievements of the project are being
            continued under the irrigation restoration and development
            project that has an estimated cost of United States (U.S.)
            147.5 million dollars over a six-year period. This new
            initiative was approved by International Development
            Association’s (IDA’s) Board of Executive Directors in April,
            2011 and the project became effective in June, 2011.
            Rehabilitation of irrigation canals and intakes will be
            further expanded nationwide as well as hydro-meteorological
            services will be further strengthened.

14291093.majtheme: Rural development,Environment and natural resource management

repnme.cdata!:
Afghanistan - Emergency Irrigation
            Rehabilitation Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Emergency
            Irrigation Rehabilitation Project for Afghanistan is to
            assist the Borrower in restoring irrigated agricultural
            production in rural areas, through improved, reliable water
            supply to rehabilitated irrigation schemes. The two key
            outcome indicators for the project development objective
            are: (i) incremental irrigated area resulting from
            rehabilitation of irrigation infrastructure; and (ii)
            increase in crop yields. Monitoring data show that as of
            October 31, 2010, the incremental irrigated area achieved
            was over 138,000 hectares compared to the end-of project
            target of 145,000 hectares. The latest annual crop survey
            carried out in 2010 also shows substantial increases
            (ranging from 21 percent to 86 percent) in crop yields as
            compared to the control group. Another significant outcome
            of irrigation rehabilitation is that water related disputes
            have reduced by 50 percent to 95 percent in rehabilitated
            schemes. The total number of project beneficiaries now
            exceeds 600,000 people. The project closing date was
            extended by one year when the first additional financing was
            approved, and by a further two and a half years when the
            second additional financing was approved, resulting in a
            cumulative extension of three and a half years. The current
            closing date is March 31, 2011.

Afghanistan - Emergency
            Irrigation Rehabilitation Project : restructuring (Vol. 2) :
            Data sheet

13197416.majtheme: Rural development,Environment and natural resource management

repnme.cdata!:
Afghanistan - New irrigation systems
            jumpstarts farming, and incomes

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about new
            irrigation systems that jumpstarted farming, and incomes in
            Afghanistan. Most of the country’s basic irrigation
            infrastructure was damaged during the conflict years, with
            only about one-third intact. As a result, the country and
            its rural inhabitants were caught in a vicious cycle, the
            productivity and incomes remained low, while food insecurity
            and rural poverty loomed large. Given the critical
            importance of irrigation water in raising the incomes of
            Afghanistan’s people, the World Bank assisted the government
            to rehabilitate and restore its irrigation systems. The
            Emergency Irrigation Rehabilitation Project  had introduced
            innovative way of supervising schemes in insecure areas.
            Under the project, local communities participated actively
            in the rehabilitation of the irrigation systems. They helped
            to identify the key constraints and contributed in kind to
            the works. The improved availability of irrigation water has
            helped boost yields of staple crops such as wheat, maize,
            and rice, as well as of onions, melons, and watermelons. The
            project helped rehabilitate multiple irrigation systems,
            benefiting over 6 million households in all 34 provinces of
            the country.

            la agricultura y los ingresos
